Support effect on the bimetallic structure of Ir–Re catalysts and their performances in glycerol hydrogenolysis Chenghao Deng Li Leng Xuezhi Duan Jinghong Zhou ⁎ Xinggui Zhou Weikang Yuan State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology 130 Meilong Road Shanghai 200237 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 21 64252169. Graphical abstract Comparative study was made between the bimetallic Ir–Re catalyst supported on amorphous silica-alumina (ASA) and the ones supported on de-aluminated ASA (D-ASA) to elucidate the effects of surface Al in the support on the Ir–Re structure and their catalytic behavior in glycerol hydrogenolysis. The Ir–Re interaction is greatly inhibited because of the stronger interaction between Re species and (Si-)Al-OH sites on ASA surface, resulting in the appearance of highly dispersed Re clusters and large Ir crystals after reduction. The barely synergy between the isolated Ir and Re metals in addition to the decreased metal dispersion restrains the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction over Ir–Re/ASA. On the other hand, the retained mobility of Re species on ‘inert’ D-ASA supports offers the intimate contact between Ir and Re species and hence the formation of Ir–Re alloy catalysts after reduction, promoting greatly the synergy between Ir and Re species in glycerol hydrogenolysis. Keywords Hydrogenolysis Glycerol Ir–Re structure Support effect Mobility 1 Introduction Reduction of the oxygen content and the length of the carbon chain via C–O or C–C hydrogenolysis is of great importance in catalysis. Especially in the area of biomass transformation, the much higher oxygen content in the biomass derivatives than fossil resources motivates the researches of selective cleavage of COH bond to obtain desired chemicals. Hydrogenolysis of glycerol, which is a main product in biodiesel industry, is considered as the model reaction for reducing the oxygen content of more complicated biomass molecules, e.g., sorbitol and xylitol [1]. On the other hand, hydrogenolysis of glycerol can produce several value-added chemicals such as propanediols and propanols (Scheme 1 ), and the most challenging target product is 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PD) [1–13]. Up to now, the most efficient catalysts [7,9–12,14–16] for hydrogenolysis of the central COH group of glycerol are mainly composed of a highly reducible metal (e.g., Pt, Ir) and species of rhenium or tungsten. The Re-modified Ir/SiO2 catalyst is a promising candidate, exhibiting both excellent 1,3-PD selectivity and high activity [8,9]. The interplay between Ir and Re is suggested to be responsible for its superior performance. It is generally accepted that Ir activates H2, while surface Re–OH group formed during reaction is likely to act as the adsorption site for glycerol [14]. However, the necessity of possessing Ir–Re vicinity has not been verified. It is known that hydrogenolysis of glycerol over bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts is a structure-sensitive reaction [8,11]. Our previous study has shown that the catalytic behavior is closely related to the bimetallic Ir–Re structure, i.e., Ir–Re alloy or Ir–ReO x structures [8]. The degree of Re reduction and the resulting bimetallic Ir–Re structure depends largely on the thermal processing procedures. Calcination of the Re precursor will expedite the formation of strong Re7+ O-support/IrO2 bonds, thus making it difficult to be reduced [14–16]. Moreover, the strength of Re7+ O-support bonds formed during calcination step depends on the nature of supports (e.g., Al2O3 and SiO2) [15,16]. On the other hand, when catalysts are directly activated before calcination, Re species in form of ReO4 − after drying can be easily reduced, independent of the nature of supports [16]. However, there remains a question to be addressed regarding the possible influence of the support on the bimetallic structure of catalysts prepared by direct reduction method. Although the Re species is fully reduced, regardless of the support, the formed bimetallic structure with Ir, which has great influences on the performance of the catalyst, may strongly depend on the nature of support, because of the different strength of metal-support interaction and mobility of metal species on support [17–21]. Moreover, silica-alumina was used as an acid additive in glycerol hydrogenolysis over bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts to maximize the activity [23]. Interestingly, the direct employment of silica-alumina as support for bimetallic Ir–Re to form a multi-functional catalyst exhibited low activity than that on silica, which was preliminarily ascribed to the presence of trace Fe on support surface by Nakagawa et al. because the performance can be improved upon HNO3 treatment [23]. Yet, the surface chemistry of silica-alumina, especially Al content, could be significantly changed during acid treatment [22]. In this context, a knowledge about the possible effect of surface Al on the structure of Ir–Re catalyst prepared by direct reduction method is desired. In this work, a comparative study on structure and performance of catalysts between the Ir–Re supported on alumina-silica material (ASA) and the one supported on de-alumina ASA(D-ASA) was made, aiming at revealing the influence of the Al in supports on the Ir–Re alloy structure. Furthermore, an in-depth knowledge into the manipulation of Ir–Re alloy structure as well as the reaction mechanism of glycerol hydrogenolysis over bimetallic Ir–Re of different structures could be obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ASA material (Aldrich, surface area=474m2/g, pore volume=0.67cm3/g) was used as received, while the D-ASA materials were obtained by treating the as-received ASA with HNO3 aqueous solution. The D-ASA-0.5 represents the ASA treated with HNO3 (0.05M) at room temperature for 0.17h, while the D-ASA-2.0 represents the ASA treated with HNO3 (0.5M) for 2h. Bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts were prepared by sequential incipient wetness impregnation of the support with H2IrCl6 (Sigma–Aldrich, 99.9%) and then NH4ReO4 (Sigma–Aldrich, 99.0%) aqueous solutions, as described elsewhere [8]. The impregnated samples were dried at 120°C for 12h after each impregnation procedure. The resulting bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts were directly reduced at 500°C in pure hydrogen (70mL/min) for 3h and subsequently passivated after cooling to room temperature in 1% O2/Ar flow (30mL/min) for 20min. The loading amount of Ir was 4.0wt% and the molar ratio of Re to Ir was 1.0. 2.2 Glycerol hydrogenolysis Hydrogenolysis of glycerol was carried out in a 100mL stainless steel autoclave (Parr Instruments) equipped with an electronic temperature controller and a magnetic stirrer. In a standard procedure, 20g of 20wt% glycerol aqueous solution, 150mg of reduced bimetallic Ir–Re catalyst and 50mg of amberlyst-15 were loaded into the autoclave. The pH value in each run was 3–4. After sealing the reactor, it was purged three times with 2MPa H2, then heated to 120°C, pressurized with 8MPa H2, and stirred at 500rpm. After reaction, the resulting reaction mixture was centrifuged, filtered and analyzed by UPLC (Waters 2414) equipped with an RI detector and a C18 AQ column. The study on the effect of acid (i.e., amberlyst-15) loading was conducted over silica (i.e., KIT-6) supported Ir–Re catalysts at the same reaction conditions. Carbon balance of liquid phase in all tests was greater than 95%. The possible gaseous product was also examined by using GC–MS, in which only trace propane was found. Conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: Conversion ( % ) = ( mol of glycerol converted ) ( mol of glycerol c h arg e d ) × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = ( mol of product ) × ( number of carbon atoms in the product ) ( Sum of carbon − based mol for all liquid products ) × 100 2.3 Characterization The aluminum contents of ASA supports were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Vanan 710). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Rigaku D/Max 2550VB/PC diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation. N2 physisorption measurements were performed at −196°C on an ASAP 2010C (Micromeritics, USA), after out-gassing the samples at 300°C and 133.3Pa for 6h. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) characterization was carried out for the reduced bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts using JEOL JEM 2100F with accelerating voltage of 200kV and a point resolution of 0.18nm. Mean particle sizes and distributions were determined by measuring over 200 randomly selected metal particles. EDX scanning for areas with large aggregates in Ir–Re/ASA was also performed. Moreover, STEM mode was employed for elemental analysis of single metal particles of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 and Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Multilab 2000 spectrometer (Thermo VH Scientific) using Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV). Binding energy was calibrated using the binding energy of the C 1s peak (284.6eV) as a reference. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out in a U-shaped quartz tube with 5% H2/Ar (30mL/min) using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The amount of sample used was 40–70mg, and the temperature was increased from room temperature to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. IR spectra of CO adsorption were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrophotometer in diffuse reflectance mode, using an in-situ cell equipped with a sample cup, heater and ZnSe windows. Pre-reduced or passivated samples were placed into the sample cup, and then reduced in-situ at 350°C in flowing H2 for 1h. The sample was cooled to room temperature, then 2% CO/Ar was introduced. After the CO coverage reached its saturation level, IR spectra were collected at 25°C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of supports The physicochemical properties of ASA, D-ASA-0.5 and D-ASA-2.0 are shown in Table 1 . As can be seen, the bulk Si/Al ratio of supports increases in the order of D-ASA-2.0>D-ASA-0.5>ASA. This indicates the de-alumination happens when treating ASA with HNO3 acid. The surface Si/Al ratio was further investigated by XPS characterization, which is higher than the bulk Si/Al ratio. Namely, the surface Al content is lower than the bulk, which is more remarkable in the de-aluminated ASA because the surface Al is very likely to be removed firstly. Notably, the D-ASA-2.0 shows trace Al on the surface, exhibiting structure of ASA encapsulated by a silica layer [22]. Moreover, the surface area of supports increases with the decrease of Al content by HNO3 treatment, which can be attributed to the pore creation during de-alumination. However, their mean pore sizes are very similar, in the range of 4.3–5.0nm (Fig. 1 ). 3.2 Catalytic performance As mentioned above, the ASA, D-ASA-0.5 and D-ASA-2.0 show significant difference in Si/Al ratio. Thus the acidity arising from the silica-alumina supports should be different. As has been shown previously [8,11,23], acidic additives can improve the activity of glycerol hydrogenolysis over bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts by probably regeneration of Re–O− to active Re–OH sites. Therefore, the possible effect of their different acidity should be excluded before providing an intrinsic relationship between the catalyst structure and the catalytic performance. Furthermore, the promoting effect of acid is shown to saturate after adding a certain amount of acid because of the certain density of surface Re species in bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts [23]. In this context, excess acid can be externally added to balance the effect of acid amount in the reactions. The influence of the amount of acidic additive, i.e., amberlyst-15, on catalytic performance of pure silica supported Ir–Re catalysts was firstly investigated, as shown in Fig. S1. Results indicate that the promoting effect of amberlyst-15 is remarkable in a certain range (10–50mg) and the activity remains almost constant when the amount of additive exceeds 50mg. Therefore, it is reasonable to add 50mg of amberlyst-15 in each run to exclude the influence of different acidity of supports, exhibiting similar pH value (3–4) of the reaction mixtures. The catalytic performances are presented in Table 2 . The Ir–Re catalysts on different supports show remarkably different performance. Ir–Re/ASA is nearly inactive, exhibiting only 4.1% conversion of glycerol at standard reaction conditions and 40.7% selectivity to 1,3-PD. In contrast, the Ir–Re catalysts supported on D-ASA materials show much higher activity. Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 and Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 shows respective ca. 9 and 12 times higher activity compared with that of Ir–Re/ASA. Meanwhile, the selectivity to 1,3-PD over Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 is markedly higher than that of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 at similar conversion, i.e., 50.0% vs. 36.5%. And the yield of 1,3-PD over Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 reaches 21.2%, which is much higher than 1.6% and 12.0% over Ir–Re/ASA and Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5, respectively. Since overhydrogenolysis of propanediols can be accelerated over more active Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 and Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 catalysts [8], the selectivity to 1-PO is thereby enhanced with the concomitantly decreased selectivities to propanediols. Moreover, the activity of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 is much higher than Ir–Re/ASA, while the difference in Si/Al ratio is not that significant. This can be explained by the removal of the surface Al on pores firstly as indicated by XPS, leaving nearly ‘clear’ surface for loading Ir–Re particles. In summary, the Al sites on ASA support seems to be detrimental to the catalytic performance of Ir–Re catalysts in glycerol hydrogenolysis. 3.3 Effect of the nature of supports on Ir–Re structure With respect to the remarkable difference in the performance between ASA and D-ASA supported Ir–Re nanoparticles, the effect of pore diameters on the diffusion of reactants/products could be firstly ruled out because their pore sizes are very similar (Table 1). However, their different surface areas as well as their different surface chemistry can play a role in influencing the particle sizes and size distributions, which will affect the catalytic performance by changing the exposure of active centers. In this regard, the possible change of particle sizes and size distributions of these catalysts were determined firstly. The typical TEM images and corresponding particle size distributions of bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts supported on D-ASA and ASA are shown in Figs. S2 and 2 , respectively. The Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 shows highly dispersed nanoparticles with mean particle size of 1.7nm and narrow size distribution, while the Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 and Ir–Re/ASA show slightly larger particle sizes with mean size of 2.5 and 2.6nm, respectively. Notably, a few large metal particles (>4.5nm) can be observed on Ir–Re/ASA (Fig. 2C). In this regard, the larger particle size of Ir–Re/ASA could be one reason for its lower activity. However, Ir–Re/ASA and Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 with almost the same mean particle size show significantly different performance in glycerol hydrogenolysis. This fact suggests that their different particle sizes are not the primary reason for their different performance. It has been shown that monometallic Ir and Re catalysts or their physical mixture are inactive in glycerol hydrogenolysis, while significantly improved catalytic performance was obtained for reaction over bimetallic Ir–Re catalyst, mainly attributed to the synergistic effect between Ir and Re [8,9]. Apparently, close Ir–Re interaction is beneficial for the formation of active Ir–Re pairs and Ir–Re synergy. In this context, the only 4.1% conversion of glycerol for Ir–Re/ASA strongly infers the barely synergy between Ir and Re (namely, very low extent of Ir–Re interaction). TEM-EDX scanning was employed to determine the chemical composition of the observed large metal particles in Ir–Re/ASA. As shown in Fig. 2D, the EDX spectrum demonstrates the presence of merely iridium in the large nanoparticles, in which rhenium is not detected. This fact strongly indicates the inhomogeneous distribution of Ir and Re on ASA, and the low extent of Ir–Re interaction as speculated above. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 3 , the STEM-EDX analysis of bimetallic Ir–Re supported on de-aluminated ASA indicates the co-existence of Ir and Re in a single metal particle for Ir-Re catalysts supported on D-ASA. The crystallinity and crystal size of supported Ir–Re catalysts are measured by XRD, as shown in Fig. 4 . The XRD pattern of Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 shows only broad peak at 20–30° due to amorphous support and no peaks attributable to metallic phases, indicating that the metal particles are highly dispersed as displayed by TEM observation, which is similar to the case observed for alloyed Ir–Re catalysts supported on silica [8]. The Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 shows only very weak diffraction peaks for monometallic Ir and Re particles. In contrast to Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5, the XRD pattern of Ir–Re/ASA with similar mean size shows sharp and strong diffraction peaks for metallic Ir crystal and a weak peak for metallic Re. This fact verifies the formation of large Ir particles, in good agreement with TEM-EDX results, and small metallic Re clusters. Even though the XRD pattern suggests the reduction of Ir and Re precursors to metallic states in Ir–Re/ASA, it is more likely that the catalyst is mainly composed of individual Ir and Re ensembles instead of Ir–Re alloy because no obvious shift of XRD peaks can be distinguished. It is reasonable to predicate the low Ir–Re synergy for this type of Ir–Re structure and its poor performance in glycerol hydrogenolysis. H2-TPR is a useful technique to study the metal-support interaction in terms of the catalysts' reduction behaviors. As shown in Fig. 5 , Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 shows main reduction peak at 144°C, corresponding to the co-reduction of Ir and Re species [8,9]. The reduction peaks of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 and Ir–Re/ASA shift to higher temperature compared with that of Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0, indicating the increased strength of metal precursors and supports interactions. It is well-known that Re species possess high oxophilicity and hence the propensity to interact with oxides through ReO bonds [15,16,24]. In this case, Re species is likely to interact strongly with hydroxyl groups (Si–OH or Si–Al–OH) on the support surface, whereas the interaction between Re species and Si–OH could be much weaker than that between Re and Si–Al–OH [15,16]. As indicated by XPS results, the surface Al content increases in the following order: ASA>D-ASA-0.5>D-ASA-2.0. To this end, the more abundant Si–Al–OH groups on Al-containing support surfaces, i.e., ASA and D-ASA-0.5, may be responsible for the increased Re-support interaction and thereby the shift of the reduction peak to high temperatures. In general, strong metal-support interaction would promote the dispersion of metals, which seems to be opposite to the cases indicated by TEM observations and XRD results. This could be explained by the different type of Ir–Re interaction. It is proposed that, for bimetallic M (Ru, Pt, Ir)-Re catalysts, addition of Re can promote the dispersion of M nanoparticles via strong interaction between Re and M [6,11,25,26]. In other words, the above-mentioned low extent of Ir–Re interaction in Ir–Re/ASA could not sufficiently inhibit the growth of Ir metals into large particles during direct reduction of iridium precursors. We deduce that the stronger interaction between Re species and Si–Al–OH groups weakens the Ir–Re and/or Ir-support interactions, thereby promoting the growth of Ir crystals as indicated by TEM-EDX and XRD results. Meanwhile, the strong interaction between Re species and Si–Al–OH group on ASA can improve the dispersion of Re as suggested by XRD pattern. Apparently, the stronger interaction between Re precursor and Si–Al–OH groups on ASA may also reduce the mobility of Re species, and subsequently results in less tendency to contact with Ir, disturbing the formation of Ir–Re pairs, analogous to the case proposed for the formation of Pt–Re alloy [21,27,28]. Similarly, the formation of isolated Re atoms/clusters on alumina via strong Re-alumina interaction was observed in previous report [24]. Notably, the marked hydrogen spillover phenomenon for Ir–Re/ASA is evidenced by the appearance of negative peak at around 520°C. The negative peak is attributable to the desorption of H species from support at high temperature [29]. Thus, even though the reduction of Re species in Ir–Re/ASA cannot be directly promoted by Ir via their intimate contact, its reduction can be promoted via hydrogen spillover effect between Ir and ASA supports, resulting in the appearance of one reduction peak for both Ir and Re species in the TPR profile of Ir–Re/ASA. The mean valence of the metal species after TPR can be estimated from the corresponding hydrogen consumption amount [9–11,14,30–32]. The valences of Ir and Re species in as-prepared Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 and Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 are estimated to be zero, indicating that the metal precursors supported on D-ASA can be fully reduced to metallic states. However, for Ir–Re/ASA catalyst, due to the severe hydrogen spillover during reduction procedure, the amount of hydrogen consumed by the metal species cannot be quantitatively analyzed to ascertain the oxidation states. It has been reported that the Re species presents as ReO4 − after drying and can be fully reduced to metallic state regardless of the type of supports (e.g., Al2O3, SiO2 and TiO2) [16]. Accordingly, we deduced that the Re species in Ir–Re/ASA could be fully reduced to metallic state, as being indicated by XRD results. In addition, in the ex-situ XPS spectra of the reduced and passivated catalysts (Fig. 6 ), we can clearly distinguish the presence of metallic Ir and Re on the catalyst surfaces in addition to their oxidized forms due to oxidation in air during sample preparation procedure. This fact further verifies that the reduction of Re is not hindered for all supported catalysts. The structure of the bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts was investigated by IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the in-situ reduced catalysts (Fig. 7 ). The Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 shows CO band at 2055cm−1, which is the intermediate position of 2068cm−1 and 2030–2050cm−1 for CO absorbed on monometallic Ir and Re [8,26,33,34], respectively. Compared with Ir–CO band at 2068cm−1, the red-shift of the CO band of Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0 indicates the formation of Ir–Re alloy, because alloying of Ir and Re leads to the electron enrichment of Ir and hence the increased electron back-donation from Ir to the adsorbed CO [8]. The Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 shows exact the same band position to the Ir–Re/D-ASA-2.0, while the band intensity is lower due to its larger metal particle sizes. The Ir–Re/ASA shows broadened CO band at 2046cm−1. Moreover, the band intensity is much lower than that of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5, even though their particle sizes are similar (2.6 vs. 2.5nm). One plausible explanation is that the CO band observed for Ir–Re/ASA might be mainly due to the CO adsorption on the highly dispersed Re0, while the contribution from CO adsorbed on large Ir crystal is less significant. Therefore, even though the mean particle sizes of Ir–Re/ASA and Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5 are similar, the intensity of CO band of Ir–Re/ASA is obviously lower than that of Ir–Re/D-ASA-0.5, because of the much lower CO chemisorption ability of Re compared with Ir [8,26,34] and larger Ir sizes (as indicated by XRD). The results described above suggest that the bimetallic Ir–Re structures and the extent of Ir–Re interaction are related to the nature of the supports. The type of Ir–Re interaction rather than the degree of Re reduction is remarkably affected by the presence of Al sites on the support surface. As illustrated in Scheme 2 , in the case of ASA, the high density of Si–Al–OH groups on the surface can result in stronger interaction between ReO4 − and surface Si–Al–OH groups than that with Si–OH groups on D-ASA. This may lead to the reduced mobility of Re species on ASA surface and thus favor the dispersion of Re species, however, hinder proximity between Ir and Re precursors. The reduction of the inhomogeneously mixed active components promotes the growth of Ir species into large metal particles due to the low extent of Ir–Re interaction. Meanwhile, the reduction of the highly dispersed Re species on ASA can be promoted via hydrogen spillover with the aid of Ir nearby, resulting in the formation of isolated Re0 clusters. In contrast, the formation of homogeneous Ir–Re alloys can be promoted on the D-ASA supports because the weaker interaction between Re and Si–OH groups can facilitate the mobility of Re species and hence the intimate contact between Ir and Re specie. Even though both Ir and Re in Ir–Re/ASA or Ir–Re/D-ASA are in metallic states after reduction, the solely existed monometallic Ir and Re on ASA cannot afford sufficient synergy in glycerol hydrogenolysis, resulting in low activity and decreased selectivity to 1,3-propanediol. Meanwhile, this fact means that the introduction of the Al sites in siliceous materials can provide intrinsic acidity to promote the reaction, but greatly prohibit the Ir–Re interaction, which results in significantly decreased the catalytic performance of the multi-functional catalyst. In a word, high mobility of Re species on supports in addition to the degree of Re reduction is crucial to obtain active Ir–Re alloy catalysts. Previous study proposed that the reaction mechanism of Ir–Re catalyst involves the metallic Ir sites and acidic Re–OH sites [8,35]. The metallic Ir can easily activate hydrogen to attack the CO bond of glycerol adsorbed on the neighboured acidic Re–OH sites. On the other hand, the present result implies strongly that the active sites for glycerol hydrogenolysis over bimetallic Ir–Re catalysts require direct interaction between Ir and Re species to exhibit sufficient synergy. This means that the present of both metallic Ir and Re on the catalyst is not enough to catalyze the reaction, while vicinity between Ir and Re is strongly recommended for better performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate the effects of Al on the bimetallic Ir–Re structure and catalytic performance in glycerol hydrogenolysis. Ir–Re catalyst supported on ASA is nearly inactive, ascribing to the detrimental effects of Al on the formation of active Ir–Re centers. Results indicate that the stronger Re-support interaction on Al-containing supports promotes the dispersion of Re species; however, hinders the intimate interaction between Ir and Re due to the reduced mobility of Re species. Consequently, large Ir particles and highly dispersed Re clusters form on ASA because of the relatively low extent of Ir–Re interaction, which show barely synergy in glycerol hydrogenolysis. In contrast, Ir–Re supported on de-aluminated ASA shows significantly enhanced activity as well as improved selectivity to 1,3-propanediol, resulting from the formation of active Ir–Re alloy nanoparticles. It is showed that the retained mobility of Re species on supports with less surface Al promotes the contact of Ir and Re. These results implies that pure silica is better than silica-alumina to support Ir–Re catalyst for glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-propanediol. In addition, attempt to introduce acid site by using Al-containing support depresses the formation of preferred alloy structure, thus impairing the overall performance of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Comparative study was made between the bimetallic Ir–Re catalyst supported on amorphous silica-alumina (ASA) and the ones supported on de-aluminated ASA (D-ASA) to elucidate the effects of surface Al in the support on the Ir–Re structure and their catalytic behavior in glycerol hydrogenolysis. The Ir–Re interaction is greatly inhibited because of the stronger interaction between Re species and (Si-)Al-OH sites on ASA surface, resulting in the appearance of highly dispersed Re clusters and large Ir crystals after reduction. The barely synergy between the isolated Ir and Re metals in addition to the decreased metal dispersion restrains the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction over Ir–Re/ASA. On the other hand, the retained mobility of Re species on ‘inert’ D-ASA supports offers the intimate contact between Ir and Re species and hence the formation of Ir–Re alloy catalysts after reduction, promoting greatly the synergy between Ir and Re species in glycerol hydrogenolysis.
coredata.dc:title: Support effect on the bimetallic structure of Ir–Re catalysts and their performances in glycerol hydrogenolysis
